siteMetadata.title: Apollo GraphQL Docs
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using Apollo Server

frontmatter.title: Mocking
frontmatter.description: Mock your GraphQL data based on a schema.

children.value: Mocking enables Apollo Server to return simulated data for GraphQL operations based on your server's schema. The strongly-typed nature of a GraphQL API lends itself to mocking, which is an important part of a GraphQL-first development process.
Mocking enables frontend developers to build out and test UI components and features without needing to wait for a full backend implementation. Mocking is also valuable when using a UI tool like
, because you don't need to start a real GraphQL server.
You can turn on Apollo Server's default mocking logic by passing
Mocking logic looks at the type returned by each schema field and returns a default value for that type.
The table below covers the default scalar types and the default mocked values returned for each type:
Returns a random positive or negative integer.
Returns a random positive or negative double-precision floating-point value.
Returns a randomized UUID containing a combination of integers and letters.
When using mocks, you don't have to specify
, you will need to specify what your server should return for those types. You can do this by creating a customized mock with resolvers for each custom scalar type, as described below.
For more sophisticated testing, you can customize your mocks to return user-specified data.
Instead of providing a boolean to the
option, you can provide an object that defines custom mocking logic. This enables you to specify values to return for different return types.
take precedence over any currently defined resolvers. In the below example, both
to define object types and the fields belonging to those object types (much like a
In the below example, note that our mocked
object calls a function returning an object with fields that contain

, a fake data generator for JavaScript that returns a different result every time the function is called. In other scenarios, such as testing, a collection of fake objects or a generator that always uses a consistent seed are often necessary to provide consistent data.
To automate mocking a list, return an array of the desired length. Using
is convenient syntax for creating an array that contains
// a list of length between 2 and 6, using the "casual" npm module
// a list of three lists of two items: [[1, 1], [2, 2], [3, 3]]

properties.ariaLabel: using existing resolvers with mocks permalink

children.value: The default behavior for mocks is to overwrite the resolvers already present in the schema. To use your server's existing resolvers while mocking, set the

children.value: The GraphQL specification allows clients to introspect the schema with a
special set of types and fields
that every schema must include. The results of a

that can be mocked as explained above.
This helps when you need to mock a schema defined in a language besides JavaScript.
Under the hood, Apollo Server's mocking functionality is provided by the function
